awd_titl_txt: SpecEES: Collaborative Research: Energy Efficient Dynamic Spectrum Access in Uncoordinated Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
With its focus on energy efficient dynamic spectrum access where the users are treated as equals and there is minimal coordination across the users, this project addresses challenges for enabling next-generation wireless communications and networking in a dynamic spectrum environment. The results from the project should greatly enhance access to broadband wireless services in traditionally under-serviced communities. The spectrum-sensing and spectrum-sharing techniques developed should prove to be equally applicable in a slew of applications involving energy-constrained ad hoc networks such as those encountered in disaster relief operations and in a variety of applications relevant to national security. The involvement of undergraduate students in this project, especially in software radio experiment, is expected to foster their long-term interest in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM)-related fields.

This research project is focused on both spectral efficiency and energy efficiency for a class of dynamic spectrum access applications that have been much less well studied: an uncoordinated wide-band system where the users are treated as equals, i.e., there is no primary/secondary distinction. The project will develop the spectrum management framework as well as enabling technologies for such applications, ranging from multi-channel spectrum sensing using quickest change detection to novel spectrum access schemes for spectral/energy efficient and fair spectrum usage in the absence of user coordination. Experimental studies are an integral part of the proposed research, and the project leverages existing software radio capabilities developed at Syracuse University. This study of spectrum access with equally privileged users without coordination also fills an important gap in dynamic spectrum access. Given the generality of the models considered, this research can be expected to make fundamental contributions to the theories of quickest change detection and random access.

por.por_cntn:
In an uncoordinated wireless system where user activities are self-sanctioned, spectrum awareness and the ability to adapt autonomously for each user are indispensable. Spectrum awareness refers to the ability to discern the spectrum environment and the presence of other users. Autonomous adaptation is the ability to select communication modes and parameters compatible with the spectrum situation in real-time. 


The project tackles both of the above aspects. With spectrum awareness, user presence and identification can often be formulated as inference problems such as anomaly detection or sequence clustering. Several important contributions have been made in this research direction, and the most significant one is the establishment of the asymptotical optimality of some popular machine learning algorithms, such as the maximum mean discrepancy in detecting deviation from a normal state. For autonomous adaptation, a simple yet effective rate adaptation scheme along spatial (across antennas) and temporal (across time) have been devised. Finally, to leverage the ubiquity of wireless signals in indoor environments, multi-function spectrum usage has been developed that can provide valuable environmental information. These new functions provide added value to existing wireless infrastructure.  


While the research tasks addressed under this project were motivated by communication challenges in uncoordinated systems, the fundamental nature of some of the research tasks can have important implications in the advancement of basic science. The award, along with some Research Experience for Undergraduate supplements, has supported a total of three doctoral students and a number of undergraduate students, several of them from underrepresented groups. The award has also facilitated the participation of a team led by the PI as a finalist in the DARPA Spectrum Collaboration Challenge. The participation of students, both graduate and undergraduate, in the DARPA challenge greatly enriched their educational experience.
